instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-02020: What is 820-02020? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP1V8_AWAKE: What is PP1V8_AWAKE? The PP1V8_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is indicative of a power rail that delivers 1.8 volts when the machine is in an "awake" state. This is not a traditional power state defined in the older Intel PCH documentation; it seems to be specific to newer MacBook architectures. The "awake" designation likely refers to a state where the MacBook is on and ready for user interaction, but it is not necessarily at full operational capacity (which would be denoted by an S0 state).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> : 5V on DV, 20V on charger, no power
threads.message:
Hi,

I got an M1 Macbook (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) with some strange behaviour.
It suffered from liduid damage around UF400, Touchpad connector, <CHIP>LP9000</CHIP> and CP870.
I removed shorted Cap CL053 and replaced UF400.

Behavior if DC only plugged:
Taking 5.23V, 0.12A (somtimes jumps up to 0.6A for a second).
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL> is quickly pulsing to between 0V and 12.3V.
<SIGNAL>PP3V8AON_PH1</SIGNAL>-3 stable 3.8V
Most other rails are pulsing.

If I connect the battery I got stable rail voltages and 20V, 0.13A on USB-C.
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_AWAKE</SIGNAL>: 1.79V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S2</SIGNAL>: 1.79V
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S2</SIGNAL>: 1.2V
<SIGNAL>PP1V25_S2</SIGNAL>: 2.8V (too high?!)
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_AON</SIGNAL>: 1.8V
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_AWAKE_PLL</SIGNAL>: 1.2V
<SIGNAL>PP0V8_AWAKE</SIGNAL>: 0.8V
<SIGNAL>PP1V25_AWAKE</SIGNAL>: 2.8V (also too high).
<SIGNAL>PP2V5_AWAKE_NAND</SIGNAL>: 2.6V
<SIGNAL>PPVDD_PCPU_AWAKE</SIGNAL>: 0.73V
<SIGNAL>PPVDD_GPU_AWAKE</SIGNAL>: 0V
<SIGNAL>PPVDD_CPU_SRAM_AWAKE</SIGNAL>: 0.85V
<SIGNAL>PPVDD_ECPU_AWAKE</SIGNAL>: 0.73V

I cant get it to DFU mode (even with battery connected). Maybe because of <SIGNAL>PP1V25_AWAKE</SIGNAL> too high?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> : 5V on DV, 20V on charger, no power
threads.message: Ok, after removing UE501 (there was some corrosion on it I didn't see) the 1V25 rails are normal and I got 20V, 0.22A and stable <SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL> on DC power.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> : 5V on DV, 20V on charger, no power
threads.message:
Did you try DFU again?

Strange to get steady <SIGNAL>3V8_AON</SIGNAL> with pulsing <SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL> before...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> : 5V on DV, 20V on charger, no power
threads.message: yes i tried dfu again but it does not work...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> : 5V on DV, 20V on charger, no power
threads.message:
Did you follow all the steps from DFU tutorial?

Try forcing the board in DFU with SV004/5.
Solder RV005 first, if not present.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> : 5V on DV, 20V on charger, no power
threads.message: Forcing th board in DFU worked. Maybe the keyboard is defective. But unforunately I can neither restore nor repair. It throws an "No such directory or file (NSPOSIXErrorDomain)" error...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> : 5V on DV, 20V on charger, no power
threads.message: Possibly bad SSD, damaged by liquid spill...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> : 5V on DV, 20V on charger, no power
threads.message: Okay bad luck for me, thank you for your help :)
